I'm a big fan of Liam Neeson. I think he's a fine actor, and a kick-ass action hero. Unfortunately, with titles such as "Taken 3" and "Cold Pursuit" lining his resume, he has been in a slew of mediocre thrillers lately. And you can add "Honest Thief" to that list."Honest Thief" is not a good film. Perhaps you may enjoy it, and I hope you do. However, I found this movie extremely boring, and relentlessly mediocre, in every aspect. Let's talk about the action. Practically nonexistent. There are maybe two or three action scenes in this film - what I mean by that is, there are only two or three scenes where fists are thrown, or guns are fired. But when the action hits, it hits like a pillow fight. It isn't necessarily poorly filmed, but the violence lacks momentum. At points Liam Neeson seems to move in slow motion, and it's a wonder that his enemies aren't able to quickly overpower him. At some points, people will just stand in place as he runs toward them, not putting up any semblance of a fight; whether this is due to bad choreography, bad direction, or both, only God knows. As a whole, the action just feels extremely sanitized, and unfortunately, it seems that Liam's age is catching up to him. At one point he yells at someone to run from the inevitable danger, while he himself is running at the pace of a slow jog.While all of the actors in this movie are good, you would not be able to know if this was the first film you've seen with them in it. In between the action you'll find extremely bland drama that is filled to the brim with wooden dialogue and stilted acting; actors sound like they're reading lines directly off the script. Jai Courtney, who I've loved in "Spartacus: Blood and Sand," was out of his element here, but I don't blame him; the horrendous writing and awkward dialogue he was forced to speak are to blame. And every actor suffers from the lackluster script writing.Ultimately, "Honest Thief" is forgettable. It feels like a movie you'd find by scrolling through TV channels late at night. There is some mildly entertaining action scattered throughout, but in the end, this movie is definitely not a theatre experience, and is one you can skip and not feel bad about missing.

So, this is your generic 'criminal finds meaning in life and wants to stop doing crime' cliche movie. There are many movies that are like this, but this one doesn't work as well, partly because the pacing is all over the place, and partly you have play really really dumb to not notice the plot holes.Like for example, that Storage Facility where Liam's character Tom meets Annie Wilkins. Apparently she's the ONLY person working there. It's not clear, does she own the place, does she just work there? If she owned the place, why was she studying for college Psychology course? LOL.Then you have the keystone cops. You could figure out a mile away that something was going to go wrong when Robert Patrick was suddenly unavailable to deal with the In and Out Bandit, so a couple of other guys are sent in his place. These two guys honestly took boxes, without confirming there was even all the money there? And didn't notice any cameras filming them? Or that lady seeing them emptying out the storage locker?Then they frame Tom with the murder of Robert Patrick's character, but their timeline of when they got there would have already been destroyed by witnesses at the front desk of the hotel, not to mention surveillance cameras at the hotel.The movie has a lot of really slow parts, completely drives the energy DOOOWN, not even the kind of breaks action movies usually need. Just draining.The last act of the movie gets really dumb. Okay, so how did Tom find Nivens house. And how did he get INTO Nivens house, and then blow it up assuming no one else was in there?! I guess after Nivens kills his partner, and then Tom lifts his shirt knowing about the recording device, that the two of them were working together to take down Nivens. Nobody even seems broken up at the end of the film about the death of that FBI agent lol. Completely forgotten. I also knew the bomb in the car would be a dud, so predictable. No way Tom would blow up 3 million, because that all had to be returned.Oh yeah, and why is everyone, including the FBI agents, shooting their guns sideways? This isn't a 90s street gang film. It's already known that doing that will jam your gun. But they were doing it 70% of the time in this film, for no reason.The movie ends with Tom turning himself in. I bet while he's in prison, that WeBoy FBI agent Meyers would probably hook up with Tom's girlfriend. They seemed to be flirting at the storage facility, and he spent a lot of time in the hospital with her. Meyers for the win lol. He better make sure Tom doesn't try to blow him up real good when he gets out..

Review title: An honest thief like a gent againt greedy officers, a common story but with its unique style. Very good Neeson as always! Worth a watch.
Review_body: Crime/action movie. Liam Neeson is an honest thief, he has broken into safes from many banks, quietly as a gentleman, without ever harming anyone. And the money he doesn't even spend it, he keeps it intact. So at some point he falls in love and thinks about leaving it all behind. So he tries to surrender and return all the stolen money, every single penny he robbed in exchange for having a reduced penalty and being able to receive visits in prison every day. Unfortunately, he's dealing with greedy officers who want to keep the money for themselves and murder him. And then the hunt begins. The film is quite gentle, without much tension or action, and Neeson really acts like an intelligent gentleman and not a criminal or action hero throughout the film. Quite a good script though not original, but in particular style on its own I would say. It is pleasantly seen and recommended although it is not one of the top movies of Neeson.

The acting is decent overall but nothing fantastic. It was great to see Donovan and he gives a good performance but his role was very underutilized. There are a few odd plot holes, especially it having FBI they miss some marks. If anything I wouldn't have rated this movie as low if they didn't wrap up the finale as fast as they did, this was a major letdown and others I was with also kinda gasped the moment the camera panned out and the credits rolled in. They really messed up there. Also there is a scene with a odd cut, that felt very rushed, you will definitely notice it (people in front of me certainly did). The VFX were also lackluster, and imo in 2020 you can't have stuff like fire/explosions look so ''greenscreen-y'' anymore. Just some really poor fire fx as well, cheap looking, not well color corrected. The action scenes were decent, not heavy on cuts or shaky cam, a little but not annoyingly.All in all it's just about alright, just not worth a ticked imo. 5/10

Review title: Was this Neeson, or Mr. Burns from The Simpsons?
Review_body: Dull B movie dialogue and B movie acting with a B movie plot. The plot is beyond stupid. These people get paid millions of dollars to crank out garbage films like this one. Spoiler alert! 10 star reviews are fake.Just another Neeson movie with nothing new to offer, other than bad dialogue and an old actor trying to play young. Sorry old people, 50 is not the new 20. Get over it. Had she dressed more appropriately for her age she would have been more attractive IMHO. Possibly dress at least 40ish??? IDK.There is also an "action" scene where old man Neeson is "running" across a street while being chased. He looked ridiculous and could barely lift his feet off of the ground. He looked like he was speed walking inside a mall, versus running.. Then he approached an eight-to-ten feet tall fence. The scene cuts with him grabbing the fence as though he is going to climb over it. Suddenly he is on the ground on the other side, facing the fence as though he climbed down. The scene looked so fake (ROFL)! Simply put he was too old and out of shape to actually do it. He looked like Mr. Burns from The Simpsons (ROFL). "Smithers." "Yes Mr. Burns?" "Climb over that fence, but make it look like I did it."45 minutes into the film you realize up to that point every scene is filled with bad acting and ridiculous dialogue. Look at the expression on their faces. It's like they would rather be fishing. Also, what's with the dog? I saw absolutely nothing added by having that dog in the film? Other than people with disabilities, who can take a dog to work everyday? Just more unnecessary nonsense.Neeson has devolved into a one trick pony. I can envision him ten years from now making Taken 8. The bad guys take his last box of Depends and he goes on a mission inside the retirement home to get them back. (LOL)There's nothing wrong with growing old when you don't live in denial. Neeson needs to let go of these so-called action roles before he falls and can't get up. He should be playing the police chief or head of a regional FBI division in these types of films versus trying to beat up everyone with his brittle bones. Neeson's generation refuses to hand over the torch like previous generations.

Review title: Nearly time to retire from action, Grandpa Neeson...
Review_body: Liam Neeson is a great actor, nobody would argue with that...but I think his days of starring in action films is over. He really shows his age in this movie with his body language and posture. I also notice some clever editing where shots are cut to show him just landing on the ground to give the impression that he just 'climbed a 10ft fence'. It reminds me of the day I watched 'Skiptrace' and realised that Jackie Chan's action days were over too.Even though it was nice to see a new Liam Neeson film that wasn't just a copy and paste of 'Taken', this film was very underwhelming. Nothing new, or original. Overused storyline of 'man tries to clear his name/crooked cops'.Acting was good though.One thing I didn't understand was what kind of neighbourhoods don't bat an eyelid when a bomb goes off in one house...and there's a 2 minute gunfight in another? Absolutely NOBODY came out, or even looked outside to see what all the noise was. Bear in mind, these are nice neighbourhoods...the kind of neighbourhoods that would call the cops if a 'strange' man was spotted simply walking down the road. Surely an explosion and a gunfight would draw attention.Summary - underwhelming, but certainly watchable.

Review title: Neesons Delivers What Fans Have Come To Expect
Review_body: Tom (Liam Neeson) is a long-time bank robber eager to put his past behind him in the new film "Honest Thief". A circumstance forced Tom to decide to strike back at the establishment following a career in ordinance in the military and has found he has a real talent for blowing safes and making away with millions of dollars over several years.The Feds have been unable to stop him and regularly field numerous calls from people claiming to be responsible in order to gain attention. So when Tom calls Agent Sam Baker (Robert Patrick) and his partner Agent Meyers (Jeffrey Donovan); his claims are met with skepticism.Tom has fallen in love with an aspiring Psychologist he met while renting a storage facility and he is eager to start a new and honest life with Annie (Kate Walsh). Tom offers to return all nine million dollars that he has stolen in term for a light sentence at a minimum security locale near Boston so Annie can visit him frequently.Unwilling to accept that Tom is who he says he is, the agents dispatch Agents Nivens (Jai Courtney) and Agent Hall (Anthony Ramos); to interview Tom and check out his story. Tom offers to tell them where the money is in order to prove his claims. When several boxes of cash are discovered in storage; Nivens decides to take the money and pressures Hall into going along with it despite his reservations.Nivens them attempts to eliminate Tom but in doing so kills Agent Baker who has shown up unexpectedly. Tom is now framed for a murder he did not commit and forced to flee in order to try to clear his name and make good on his initial offer to turn himself in.Nivens is not willing to stop there and escalates his level of corruption and danger including threats on Hall and his family to ensure his compliance and silence.As anyone who has ever seen a Liam Neeson film in the last ten years or so can deduce his character is motivated by events that follows and with his expert knowledge of explosives looks to strike back at Nivens and ensure justice is served.While the film may be a bit slower paced in some areas than fans of Neeson may expect; he turns in a satisfying performance as a sort of modern day Robin Hood.Tom is a man who does not make excuses for his actions and is willing to pay the price for them but believes he was justified in what he did and the reasons behind them.The supporting cast is solid and while the film does have some real gaps in logic which must be suspended to make the story work; it does entertain.In the end "Honest Thief" provides enough enjoyment to make it worth your time and shows that Neeson still can deliver what fans have come to expect from him.3.5 stars out of 5

Review title: There was potential but it ends up being a visually boring action movie
Review_body: Honestly, I am a sucker for Liam Neeson action flicks. Yeah, they are dumb or over the top but at least it is entertaining with its ridiculous action set pieces. Honest Thief is the next in the list of Liam Neeson's action movie résumé. The premise is "Hoping to cut a deal, a professional bank robber agrees to return all the money he stole in exchange for a reduced sentence. But when two FBI agents set him up for murder, he must now go on the run to clear his name and bring them to justice". Does this movie hit the mark or did it steal my time that I won't get back?Firstly, Liam Neeson is still great to watch with his gravelly voice and the fact that despite his age he is still throwing convincing punches. Tom Dolan (Liam Neeson) is the centre of this movie and for the most part, is a decent character to watch. Annie Wilkins (Kate Walsh) who is Tom's love interest and the girl that makes him give up robbing banks is okay as well. The moments between the two are quite sweet to watch and there is some chemistry there that we the audience can invest in.The premise is also mildly interesting despite being kind of cliche. It's another action movie where someone is framed for something they didn't do and they have to prove themselves. Ironically, Liam Neeson has done movies like this already such as "Non-stop" and "The Commuter". However, there are some bits and pieces in there that could make the movie interesting such as him being framed by corrupt cops and that he Tom isn't a badass murderer. The first half of the movie is also pretty enjoyable because it spends time on its characters. It develops the backstory of the characters, their relationships and individual quirks. The movie doesn't just develop the main leads but also the veteran cops and the corrupt cops as well. It is quite refreshing to see. There is also this running gag with wisecracking veteran agent Meyers (Jeffrey Donovan) and the adorable scruffy dog he inherited from his recent divorce.It's a shame the second half decides to abandon all of the interest in the characters. The movie becomes a more generic action movie with boring car chases, not spectacular fistfights and some mediocre shoot outs. What could have been complicated characters, become just generic and one-note characters. An example is one of the corrupt cops Nivens (Jai Courtney) who makes a good point about taking the money that the audience might agree with but then becomes generic evil greedy dude.The movie is just incredibly predictable and all the suspenseful moments such as the shady dealings aren't as impactful as it should be. I would have probably liked the movie more if the action scenes were at least visually pleasing to watch but it isn't. Additionally, there some are weird choices made by characters that are just really silly and can take you out of the movie. For example, a character has been shot repeatedly which the main character Tom saw. Instead of checking if he is still okay or calling a hospital he instead decides to do a phone call first right next to a dying or dead person. It's a weird director decision and it just makes the character seem weird.Overall, the movie is just very mediocre. There is something interesting buried within this movie with characters dealing with guilt and personal responsibility but they are unfortunately not explored. Furthermore, the action scenes are boring and not that exciting. This is what makes the movie disappointing as the pieces for a stronger movie are there but not utilised. If you like Liam Neeson then there is worth watching it for him alone but you want a fun action movie then this isn't it.
In the past I've had issues with Neesons characterization, but this film is all together different, it actually kept me glued to his character.

All she had to do was listen for one second and stay on the bus. It was so infuriating watching as the only way he could get lured into trouble was because of her stupidity. Review title: Not the best Neeson, but quite successful still.
Review_body: Between the first one and this one has accommodated a few weak "Liam Neeson" movies. Today, he is expected to have quite action-oriented films, even though the Lord is already somewhat old.This definitely belongs to the better end.While the start didn't give too good a picture and the progress during the first half hour was pretty slow, one could say drama about the emphasis, although it's good to shed light on the backgrounds that do justice to things and events in the film. Due to the initial slowness and a little too little activity, I couldn't give a better rating, but the film ends up on the shelf, sometimes.And that dog, it was wonderful!

First off, there is zero chemistry between Neeson and Kate Walsh. It doesn't help that a good portion of the dialogue spoken between the two during scenes intended to be intense, is delivered with all the enthusiasm of reading the Sunday obituaries. Neeson, in particular, just doesn't seem invested. Oddly enough, Jai Courtney gives the most thrilling performance here as an FBI agent gone rogue in an attempt to steal the $9 million that Neeson's character, Tom Dolan, dubbed the In-and-Out Bandit, stole over a decade of performing solo bank heists. So, yeah, when Jai Courtney gives one of the better performances in a film, that's pretty sad.As heist movies go, or really any movie, scriptwriters here must think audience members are pretty braindead because the plot of this movie is so asinine and cringeworthy, Honest Thief isn't very watchable. Plus, not much of what the characters do make any damn sense in real life.This movie's problems are numerous. First off, Dolan robbed twelve banks over an extended number of years and authorities and the media obviously knew his modus operandi enough to dub him the In-and Out Bandit. So, why wasn't he caught sooner? I ask because Dolan's requirements for which bank he would target are so specific there's no way he wouldn't have been caught prior to robbing twelve banks. He always selects banks in small towns with a specific, older type of vault that is easier to crack than modern vaults and the banks ALWAYS have an adjoining vacant building through which he gains access to the bank. In addition, Dolan only does the heists during a 3-day weekend. Question: How often would such specific opportunities come together for Dolan to pull off the perfect heist? Answer: Very rarely. So, the FBI would have been all over this and figured out he was using adjoining vacant buildings to gain access to banks after, like, his third or forth successful robbery. They would have issued a memo to all older banks in small towns to inform the FBI when adjoining buildings go vacant and those banks would have been under heavy surveillance during every 3-day holiday. Dolan would have long ago been caught.But what's worse about this plot is that Dolan claims he plasters the walls and paints after the heist so that authorities don't know how he got into the bank. Well, duh, it still wouldn't take long to figure out he got in via the vacant adjoining building! Also, even if he could plaster/patch the wall (and match the paint color perfectly) on the vacant building's side of the hole in the wall, how did he do the same on the bank's side of the wall? The answer is he would not be able to plaster, patch, and paint the hole on the bank's side of the wall and so, authorities would have known from day one how he got "in and out" of the bank (pun intended).As for Dolan's motive for robbing banks? He did it initially to get back at the corrupt CEO who made off with his dead father's pension. Yes, this is pretty stupid. Because even if you rob a bank where the CEO of the company your dad worked for keeps his money, you're not taking the CEO's money directly, you're taking the bank's money. Any money you steal from the bank will likely be replace via the bank's blanket bond or some other form of insurance. What did Dolan think? The bank would have a vault just for the CEO with his name on it where he keeps hard cash? LMAO. NO! Plus would a CEO, even an unscrupulous one, keep all his money in a small town bank in the first place? Wouldn't he diversify his money in various investments instead or bank at a private bank for high-net-worth individuals which is not likely to have a branch in a small town? How stupid do the writers of this film think the average viewer is? Honestly?Also, why would you attempt to turn yourself in from a hotel? If you're trying to work out a deal in return for giving back the entire $9 million, doing it from a hotel gives you no better advantage than doing it from the FBI facility. Those low-level FBI agents wouldn't be the ones that could broker him a deal anyway. Has this guy Dolan ever watched any legal drama or crime drama series on TV? SMH. It's the prosecutor and your criminal defense lawyer who would do that, and, hello, you're no where near that step yet when just turning yourself in!Also, if you're a crooked FBI agent planning to steal the $9 million your suspect is leading you to in a nearby storage facility, why wouldn't you bring him along when he said he's turning himself in if your ultimate goal is to kill the suspect? You've already had twelve individuals falsely claim to be the In-and-Out Bandit and your superiors clearly believe this to be another dead-end lead. You cuff him and take him with you so that he's easier to dispose of once you get the loot. You don't leave him at the hotel. He might change his mind and flee while you're at the storage facility.Also, writers want us to believe this guy stole $9 million over several years and never spent even one penny of it? LMAO. This, much like the plot of Blood Brother (2018), is probably the most farcical and insulting aspect of the entire dumb plot.
You are a thief and you trust two FBI agents not to steal the money? Give me a break. But, I will give it a chance.

I perused the other reviews for this movie and was shocked by how many people didn't like it. Everyone has different opinions I suppose. I just know that really enjoyed it! I took off a couple stars because one guy died that I wanted to live AND I wanted there to be a fast forward at the end. You know, like two years later or something?The basics of this movie are as follows. Tom robs numerous banks over several years. You'll find out later why. He always did it at night, so no one was in any danger. Tom goes to a self storage lot to hide his millions and hits it off with Annie, who runs the place. They date for a year and Tom falls hard for her. He wants to be a better man for her. In his mind, the only true way to redemption is to turn himself in and give the money back. So, Tom calls the FBI and confesses, but the agents are skeptical because they've received over a dozen false confessions thus far. He had to keep calling them until finally two agents (John and Ramon) come to his hotel room. Tom gives details of his crimes, but the agents are still unsure without the physical money evidence. So Tom gives them a key to his storage locker and the two agents find $3 million. But instead of turning it in, they decide to keep it. Ramon is uncertain but goes along with the plan anyway. They return to Tom's hotel room and are going to kill him, but he says that there is still $6 million hidden away. About this time, one of the head agents comes to the hotel room and is murdered by John, once he figures out something is off. Then Tom fights John and Ramon, falling out of the window with one of them. Annie happens to be coming to the hotel and witnesses the fall. They take off and Tom has to finally explain what is happening. And now the the FBI is coming after him for murder, even though John is responsible. There is quite a bit of action after this, including John beating up Annie, Ramon being shot by John, car chases, shootouts, John's house being blown up, and more. Luckily, another FBI agent, Sean, starts to believe Tom's version and eventually is able to arrest John.You have to suspend belief during some of this movie, but isn't it like that with most? That's why films are made! We get to leave our lives and jump into another for a bit. My favorites: Annie's reaction to Tom blowing up John's house, the blow up itself, how Tom got John arrested, the fact that Tom never killed anyone or tried to, Agent Sean and his dog, and the relationship between Annie and Tom. My least favorites: The death of Ramon and the nonchalant attitude of the FBI.
What else can you say . You'll know exactly what to expect , thrills , spills, shooting and fighting with a bit of a daft story !!Special bonus is a very cute dog .

Review title: At least it was only 99 cents
Review_body: There are just too many things that don't make sense. So Liam wants to turn himself in and go to jail so he can have a relationship with his girlfriend. But he doesn't want to go to jail for very long so he wants to be punished, just not very much. Ok. For starters, wouldn't it probably be a good idea to tell his girlfriend first what he was planning to do? And no, the fact that he tried doesn't count because he was under no time clock, he can turn himself anytime, so he could easily tell his girlfriend first that he was a bank robber and that he was going to turn himself in. What was his plan anyway, even if it went properly - as he's led off in handcuffs by FBI agents, and his girlfriend is standing there, he was going to say what, oh by the way honey, I'm a bank robber and I just turned myself in, see you when I see you, hope you're still around in a couple of years because I'm doing it all for you? Ok. But then why does he even need to turn himself in? It was a victimless crime essentially and he never spent any of the money, so why not just return the money anonymously, clear his conscience and go on with life? Seems fair and reasonable. Again why not discuss it with his girlfriend first? Maybe he would find out she was ok with him being a bank robber, she certainly doesn't seem to mind when he blows up a house, and maybe if her first question was, how much did you steal with a grin on her face, he would know there was really nothing to worry about. Even if she wasn't ok with it, quite likely she would be okay with return the money or give the money to charity or something along those lines. And if he still insists on wanting to be punished, just not too much, maybe she could punish him for being a bad boy. Still he wants to turn himself in. Ok. But doesn't go to a lawyer to see what kind of deal he can cut. Doesn't just go into FBI headquarters, which would make a lot more sense, he would still have the money as leverage, and that way he could really prove who he said he was, maybe bring along one packet of money, good chance they had all the serial numbers. Instead he calls in and asks for a deal. First of all, how is that up to FBI agents to cut him a deal? Is that not something for the prosecutor to decide? And even if the FBI agents agree, just to get him to confess, what, does he really think they would be under any obligation to actually keep the deal? What was he going to say after they arrested him and he was charged with multiple cases of grand larceny, hey, no fair, you said you were going to cut me a deal? Yeah, right. Still he makes the call. And the FBI take it with no reports being made, nothing entered on record, no paper trail being created in effect. Instead Robert Patrick, after assigning it to two other agents, goes to the hotel by himself. At this point, he doesn't know who he's dealing with, Liam might be insane or an actual bank robber - maybe bringing a partner might make sense. But he goes alone and gets smoked. I'll cut ahead a little because there's just too much stupidity to cover, but the point is somehow Liam knows that of the two bad agents, one is a really bad agent, while the other one is only kind of bad. How exactly does he know this? The less bad agent was there when the good agent gets killed and the really bad agent also tries to kill Liam, including a big chase scene in which they're both after him and also Kate Walsh at that point; he's also there when the really bad agent beats up Kate and tries to kill her, but the less bad agent only thinks she's dead (more stupidity - how exactly is someone only maybe dead, either you have a pulse or you don't), and they both leave her for dead anyway; the less bad agent is along for the ride when they find Liam and have a massive shoot out between the car and van (a Marine and a bad FBI agent, yet neither of them can hit the broad side of a barn at close range) - and from this, Liam somehow magically ascertains that one is a really bad agent because he steals money and kills a good agent and tries to kill him and Kate and frame him, while the other agent is only kind of bad because he only steals money, doesn't say anything about the good agent getting killed, leaves Kate for dead and tries to frame him? Ok. Another one, Kate is in the hospital, a material witness involved with a bank robber and the possible killer of a good agent, yet she doesn't get any protection and there aren't like twenty agents standing around, ready to question her as soon as she regains consciousness? Ok. But back to the bad agent, less bad agent. Liam tracks down the less bad agent, the less bad agent says he has the tape of the storage with them loading the boxes into the car - so why doesn't Liam take it right there and then and go to the other good agent with the evidence? What, was it buried in the guy's back yard and the map was an Indiana Jones map on a medallion? And why not just demand that the less bad agent confess to the other good agent of his role and turn State's evidence against the really bad agent and cut a deal? There was never a chance where the less bad agent wasn't going to have to face some kind of punishment so why not just come clean right there? One more about the less bad agent saying that he stole the money because of how much he loved his family - how about the fact that he would never be able to look his kids in the eyes again because he would always know that the good man they thought they were looking at was a liar and a thief? That wouldn't have been more important to him than some ill gotten money? I could probably go on but that's enough. And to think that's in a movie less than a hundred minutes long. Wow.

Usually I pick movies for the plot, but with Liam I'll give his movies a watch because I like watching him. I struggled through Ice Road. This I'm giving up on a third of the way in. It's just too bland and daft to watch. Neeson's character is too boring to be true. The plot is absolutely ludicrous. We've supposed to believe he robbed twelve banks but each time just put the cash in a box in storage and never spent a penny of it? Seriously? Now he wants to give it all back even though no one knows who he is and he's actually found a good use for the money? It would have been so easy to add a credible reason into this awful writing: have him kill or wound someone in the last robbery and that makes guilt overwhelm him. Have him get a terminal illness so he comes to see the true value of money. Anything but this dross! Sheesh. Wooden characters, plodding plot, predicable outcome. Oh, for the days when Liam was given a decent movie to be in.

Liam Neeson is a very fine actor and I enjoyed most of his previous movies. What really puzzles me, though, how come such fine actor like him could agree to play in the movie with such idiotic script?In the movie he plays a bank robber with 100 percent of successful robberies, that is, no one could catch him or figure out who he is. Then he meets a woman, fells in love and decides to 'go straight.' Very noble, indeed. But here the stupid, or rather, idiotic part starts: instead of returning the money he robbed or at least giving it to charity while sending an anonymous letter promising that he won't ever do it again, he decides to turn himself in. He realizes that he will have to do time, probably a lot of time in the jail while he's not a 'spring chicken' that is, at his age every year counts. So instead of spending each and every year that remained in his life with the woman he loves, while returning the money and 'doing time' as any other normal person in his position would do, that is, getting involved in the community, doing charity work, etc., he just turns himself in while hoping that the government would appreciate his noble gesture and gives him a reduced sentence. So he comes across two greedy FBI agents who after probably realizing what idiot they are dealing with decide to take his money and kill him. And here the typical action starts. Naturally for this kind of movie, after lot of car chasing and shooting the bad guys are killed or arrested and the 'good' FBI agent receives the stolen money and, as a nice gesture, allows him to hug his girlfriend for the last time before taking him in. Oh, boy.. Sure, the viewers should be educated that it is not good to rob banks and there's a price to pay for that, but here the political correctness goes overboard.I really felt sorry for poor Liam in such a stupid role and also felt myself robbed for almost two hours of my time by watching this garbage.

As a physician, I can tell you that there is no way to get past the ER waiting room and security unless you need to be there. How Liam's character manages this transfer is never shown. Instead of investigating the murder and attempted murders himself, the agent supervisor lets Liam's character do it himself. It was another fun action movie from Liam Neeson, but the plot was really stupid.

I doubt calling the FBI would be the way to go, nor handing two jokers the keys to your ill-gotten-gains. He wasn't such a master after all.So after 46 minutes I had to switch off, the plot just continued to frustrate.

I didn't expect much but I was a little disappointed.The story is very weak. While there are movies that are able to build a convicing story around this kafkaesk battle "man against corruption" this movie clearly didn't think it through. The corrupt agents "big plan" was so amateurish that the viewer never has any doubts that the truth will come out. The writers couldnt even come up with a reason why the FBI should still think that Neeson is the bad guy. So, for most of the movie its just Neeson (ex marine and IQ 300 bankrobber) against one single corrupt dimwhit FBI agent. I wonder who is going to win this...In good "man against governement" movies you often times have this single piece of evidence that the main character produces in the last moment and completely turns the ending aorund - thats exciting. This movie couldn't be bothered. In general there was no sense of urgency, Neeson is always ten steps ahead - how does he know where to show up, only the writers know.I can't say the movie is a disaster. Its watchable but its hard to enjoy this combination of bland actors and lazy script. This movie will be forgotten quickly.

I'm super hyped to talk about this movie. I just got out of the theatre, and this is one of those movies that I think will be reverberating through my mind for a little while. It's not profoundly poetic or anything like that, nor is it anything like a mindless Liam Neeson action flick with a big conspiracy and a big reveal that doesn't do much for the plot or the audience. I'll admit, I only went to see this cuz Liam is my boy and I wanted to go see a movie in theatres and there was nothing else that interested me. I've been on a sci fi kick lately, and I was not really feeling this movie before I went. But from the first scene, my fears of the needlessly overcomplicated conspiracy and cheapness of Liam Neeson's other movies (which I love about them, I just wasn't feeling them today) slowly disappeared as the film went on. There is no mystery here; you're with every character the entire way through. It's so awesome to see them each in their own little zone and hear their backstories that are sprinkled throughout the movie, and we also get to see them grow and change. It's all so subtle, and it's a shame that people probably won't give this movie the time of day. Great characters, compelling motives, awesome performances, and gnarly action make for one dynamite movie!!!!

Review title: typical story with a twist - but an averagr Liam Neeson flick
Review_body: Decided to give this a watch on Netflix.What can I really say, it's an interesting take a thief story wanting turn himself in from the banks that he robbed, and then it gets very Lian Neeson. What I mean by that, is he fights the 'bad' people to do the right thing.I mean I was expecting a film like 'Taken' and for the most part, thats what I got. I mean he tends to play the same role every film, weather he would be an ex-marine, ex-cop, ex-spy agent, he just always plays the same roles, yet i'm not bothered by it. I guess maybe because he's good at it.The Acting - was decent enough, the typical Liam Nieeson lines are there, but not as.that one taken line that was made into a meme, but still decent.I don't necessarily believe the love story between Tom.& Annie, and they kind rushed on his whole point of wanting to be a better guy because of her.They did however go into enough detail on why he did what he did in the past, and I understood it and felt for the character once hearing the story.The Antagonist in the film was well played too.- Jai Coutney did a great job, perhaps I would have liked him to be a bit more psychotic, but I certainly felt his greed.The film isn't ove rthe top, and isn't bad, it's an average okay film, that you might maybe stop and watch if it randomly shows on tv, cause Liam Neeson always seems to have that.watchability factor - perhaps it might be the voice :P.6 / 10 - If You like Liam Nieeon you'll find this movie decent, it's not the best action flick, or the greatest story about second chances, but the story takes a multitude of things that has been done before, and adds a certain kind of twist to it, which makes it less different than other Liam Neeson films.

Review title: Lazy screenwriting makes for a terrible movie

These plot holes are so huge you could walk a herd of elephants thru them. And the lazy screenwriters don't even bother with covering their laziness! For example, (spoiler alert) at one point the protagonist decided to secretly get his girlfriend out of the hospital. How is it shown in the movie? He walks into her hospital room, tells her we need to get out of here... and the next scene we see is the two of them in his hotel room. We're supposed to believe that nobody in the entire hospital noticed a patient being "secretly" walked out? And why should we believe that that's possible, if even the screenwriters didn't believe it possible themselves, so they quickly cut to the hotel room? And the whole movie is just like that. Terrible, just plain terrible. Even Liam Neeson is terrible in it too, showing the emotional depth of a cardboard box. My only guess is that once he signed the contract and got the money, he decided not to waste any acting on this sad excuse of a movie.

Review title: Watchable, but also a game of "who can spot the greatest number of plot holes"

But seldom have I seen such poor script-writing, to the extent where it quickly becomes a distraction.Others have already pointed out dozens of plot holes, inconsistencies and actions that are out of character. I'll name just one (but there are many that are worse): Dolan takes the gun of one of the dirty FBI agents; a couple of days later he hands it to the agent's superior, who gives it back to the dirty cop saying "I believe this belongs to you" (or something to that effect). An FBI agent not filing a report about losing his gun? I'm sure they have to file a report on every time they fire one or more bullets, let alone when their gun has been taken away from them by a cop killer.

The movie does the job to entertain us and to re-introduce: Jai Courtney as the bad guy that we know that he can be, Jeffrey Donovan who can be a real treat when paired with a good script and a relative new comer in Anthony Ramos, who is yet another Hamilton Original Cast member to keep in mind. Having said that, the movie is far from perfect; there were plenty of shaky moments, yet the unpredictability and mystique in Neeson's role is just enough to keep you (somewhat) on the edge of your seat.

Review title: Typical Neeson Movie Still Enjoyable - Minor Spoilers
Review_body: Liam Neeson plays his typical role of former military/law/operative/combat veteran in the way of a former marine that eventually turned to robbing banks. Thanks to his explosive training in the Marines, he was able to get in and out of banks to blow the vault and steal money. Over the course of nearly a decade he was able to steal 9 million dollars.In the beginning of the movie he runs into a woman who owns a storage unit business and ends up falling in love with her. He loves her so much he turns away from robbing banks and wants to wipe his slate clean and turn himself into the police, return the money, but on his terms and his agreement of a reduced sentence, minimum security, and special visitations within an hour of where he is.The FBI sends a couple agents named Nivens and Hall to speak with Neeson's character Tom to see if he is telling the truth. They do not suspect he is the real "In and Out Bandit" (which Tom hates the name by the way) because there is always people calling in claiming to be the bandit. Once they get to the hotel Tom is staying in they talk with him and he tells them a story only the real bandit would now. The agents still don't believe him and Tom offers to take them to where the money is housed. The storage units owned by Tom's love interest Annie. The agents tell him to stay put and they would look and be back. This then turns to the agents going to the storage unit and find boxes upon boxes of money. Hall wants to turn in the money and do his job. Nivens wants to take the money and write Tom off as another "In and Out Bandit" imposter and split the money with Hall. Nivens feeds on the fact that Hall is a family man with a wife and kids and tells him how much that money could help him and his family. Hall eventually goes along with it and they go back to the hotel to kill Tom so they can escape with the money.Without giving away too much, this turns into a cat and mouse chase between Tom and the agents. The agents, led by Nivens plans, tries their best to get Tom off their trail and kill him but Tom, being a former marine and explosive expert, is smarter and tougher than they think. They find out their theft of his money doesn't go anything like they planned. You don't steal from a man who wants to be an Honest Thief and start over life with the woman he loves.

Review title: Patrick and Neeson should have switched roles
Review_body: Decent concept, a bit thin on believability and Liam Neeson was the wrong person for the lead. Why? Because he's 15 years older than Kate Walsh (can't believe Annie would fall for Tom with that age difference) and he's not a believable American character (be can't hide his Irish accent - at least they could have made his character a former UK Marine) and he talks and runs like the 68-year-old that he was when this film was shot.Robert Patrick is a great actor and I liked his role, right up until they offed him at beginning of Act 2. I was sad to see him leave so soon.Also, setting this in Boston seems kind of random since absolutely nobody in the film has a Boston accent (thank God), except Jeffery Donovan as Sean Meyers, who makes a little effort at being Bostonian. This might have made more sense to be in San Francisco, a finance city.Just before the midpoint, Tom is sending Annie away and Annie says, "Come with me." And then 10 seconds later, she is resolved to leaving alone and says, "Prove it, Tom. Prove that you didn't kill that man." This feels unrealistic especially with the scene that puts Annie with no pules, then in the hospital, and then he's gets to go hard core on the crooked agents with her all better.One thing I did like... Neeson riding around in a '78 F-100 with round '77 headlights.My parting shot: they should have cast Patrick as the sympathetic lead and ex-marine "Tom Dolan" (see Patrick in The Unit) and Neeson as the salty FBI agent "Samuel Baker" (Neeson plays salty better than bar pretzels). At least Patrick is 6 years younger than Neeson and closer to Walsh's real age, to make the love story more believable.
